momPost.overlayTitle: When Your Brain Is Just… Noise
momPost.overlaySubtitle: Burned out, running on fumes, still showing up
momPost.hook: Days start to feel like that jumble of letters in your head — asdfas dfas fsad — just chaos, no space, and you still have to keep everyone alive.
momPost.imagePrompt:
3:4 minimalist infographic, off-white background. Clean, pastel color palette of soft mint, blush pink, warm beige, and pastel teal. 
      At the top: simple flat vector illustration of a tired mom sitting at a kitchen table, messy counter around her, head in hands. A soft mint bubble above her head filled with jumbled letters and scribbles, fading into calmer, more ordered lines toward the right side, showing her brain quieting a bit. Same messy room, but her shoulders are lower, face softer. 
      Main title area below the illustration, large bold text. 
      Under that, 3 stacked sections with rounded rectangles:
      1) "Right Now" in blush header band with 3-4 bullet phrases, each with tiny line icons (small lightning bolt, drooping battery, tangled scribble).
      2) "What You Actually Need" in soft mint with bullet phrases and tiny icons (heart, pause symbol, small leaf).
      3) "Your 3-Minute Reset" in pastel teal with bullet phrases and icons (clock, spark, gentle wave).
      At the very bottom, a warm beige band with one simple reassurance line in clear text. 
      Modern flat vector, soft rounded shapes, high-contrast text, generous padding, plenty of white space, no clutter, optimized for phone readability.
momPost.caption:
A. HOOK  
Your days feel like that random string of letters.  
Everything blurs together.  
You’re running on empty, still loading the dishwasher, still answering “Mooooom?” every five seconds.  
You lie down and your brain is still shouting to-do lists and guilt.

B. NORMALIZE  
This isn’t you “failing.”  
This is what happens when a human runs past her limit for too long.  
Of course you’re snappy. Of course you feel numb.  
You’re not ungrateful or broken.  
You’re burned out and still trying. That matters.

C. TINY WIN (WHAT MOMMIRROR DOES IN 3 MINUTES)  
MomMirror is like a tiny pause in the hallway before you walk back into the chaos.  
In 3 minutes, it helps you:  
- Take a few real breaths so your body stops sounding the alarm.  
- Untangle one loud thought from the pile so it feels less like static.  
- Hear a kinder voice than the one in your head.  
- Pick one tiny, doable next step… or give yourself permission to do nothing for a moment.

D. IDENTITY SHIFT (BIG MARIO)  
You don’t need a whole new life.  
You need small moments where you feel like a person again, not just a service robot.  
Big Mario you is still tired, dishes still in the sink…  
But your shoulders are lower. Your chest isn’t so tight.  
You speak to yourself the way you speak to a friend.  
You move through the same mess, but you’re not drowning in it.

E. SOFT INVITE  
You’re allowed to need help calming your own mind.  
If your brain feels like “asdfas dfas fsad” all day, you don’t have to fix everything.  
Just start with three minutes to breathe, notice, and be gentler with yourself.
